reviewText: This is the saddest movie you're likely to see ever, not so much for the wrenching intimate tragedy it portrays but for the historical reality that it epitomizes. Could you possibly make sense of this film if you knew nothing at all about the mass murder of Jews in Hitler's Germany and the lands that Germany occupied? I don't think so! Fortunately, there are few people that ignorant of history alive right now, although there are a vicious few who deny it. Clearly, this is a film not just about two boys but also about the species that labels itself scientifically as Homo sapiens -- "Human knowing".Having survived 60% of the Twentieth Century, I can testify that it was the most tragic on record. Yeah, yeah, we were born with higher life expectancies and we had shinier toys. But it was the century of mass murder, conducted by the polity that we had supposedly evolved to manage our savagery. The most extensive mass murders were generated by ideologies wrapped in racism and nationalism, and sometimes sheathed with phony science. Do I need to indict the murderers here? Nearly all of Europe, even including France, had temporary governments that helped Hitler murder Jews. Stalin's USSR murdered uncountable millions. Cambodia. Uganda. Rwanda. Chile. Argentina, El Salvador and more ... murderous governments. Those rabid denouncers of the national/federal government of the USA should take note: though racism and xenophobia and fanaticism thrived in the USA also in the 20th C, the federal government never fell into the paws of the mass murderers. In fact, though the feds were guilty of segregationist behavior and repression of some forms of thought, much more obviously the federal government took effective measures to moderate the racist behaviors of state governments and of "us the People."What does this have to do with a movie review? Everything! Because this movie made me think of history at every frame. It also made my wife cry on my shoulder disconsolately, and it made my teenage son turn off his laptop and stop wise-cracking for the rest of the evening. If you haven't already been informed of the scenario, here it is: Bruno's father, an ambitious and convinced Nazi military officer, is appointed to command a "work camp" -- really a death camp -- in a remote rural area. He takes his family there. His 8-year-old son, Bruno, finds a way to sneak out of the safe but boring home compound. Bruno finds the fence that surrounds the imprisoned Jews and makes contact with a boy his age, in a striped uniform that Bruno takes for pajamas. Sitting on opposite sides of the barbwire, the two naive boys form a bond....Some reviewers have objected that the boy Bruno, the central character, was implausibly naive, even for a pampered and protected eight-year-old. But the boy is something bigger than a single child; he's a synecdoche of the Germans (and Americans!) who "didn't know" and couldn't believe and perhaps couldn't care enough until it was too late. I suppose I'm taking the film as an allegory.Bruno's father and grandfather, seemingly decent men committed to duty and patriotism, are in fact "whited sepulchers" of ideology gone mad. They are surely Goldhagen's "willing executioners." The mother and grandmother are shown to be conscience-stricken, but they too are executioners, unwilling if you want to defend them, but guilty of passivity.  Once again thinking allegorically, I'm tempted to see all of Germany's postwar agony on the faces of the horrified parents.If this movie seems more to you than an evening's vicarious 'entertainment,' I suggest that you get acquainted with the books of W. G. Sebald, especially "Austerlitz" and "The Emigrants." Sebald is postwar Germany's greatest writer and most profound analyst of guilt.

reviewText: THE BOY IN THE STRIPED PAJAMAS is a 'compleat' motion picture: even the title states the vision of the film in a subtly powerful way. Based on the excellent novel by John Boyne and adapted for the screen by director Mark Herman, this film has the courage to re-visit the Holocaust from the child's perspective.  Not that it covers up the atrocities of that horrid event and time - quite the opposite: in electing to examine that period in history the stance is that of two children, one German son of an officer in Hitler's armed forces and one son of a Jewish captive living with his father in a concentration camp.  The juxtaposition of these two eight year old boys separated not only by a fence but by an ideology neither of them can fathom the other's side makes for not only a brilliant film but also an unforgettable emotional experience.Bruno (Asa Butterfield in an extraordinary performance) is eight, his sister Gretel (Amber Beattie) is twelve and the two live with their parents in 1940 Berlin - father (David Thewlis) is a Komandant in  Hitler's army and mother (Vera Farminga) is a popular socialite and loving mother.  Father is 'promoted' and will be in charge of a new 'position' that means moving from their beautiful Berlin home to a 'home in the country'. Though Bruno doesn't want to leave his friends the family does indeed move - to a cold house next to what Bruno perceives is a farm. The father is forbidden to share his role and the meaning of it with his family, but it soon becomes obvious by the smoke stacks spewing hideously smelling odors into the atmosphere that the 'farm' is a concentration camp. The house servant Pavel (David Hayman), though abused by the father, becomes Bruno's friend when Bruno sustains an injury: Pavel quietly admits to Bruno that despite his 'pajama' uniform from the 'farm' that he practiced medicine in the past.  Bored, Bruno explores the forbidden area outside his home confines and finds a barbed wire electrified fence behind which sits Shmuel (Jack Scanlon) who becomes Bruno's friend.  Neither lad understands the differences between them until Shmuel is sent into Bruno's household to polish glasses for a party: the armed forces chauffeur Lieutenant Kotler (Rupert Friend) beats the 'little filthy Jew' for eating pastries Bruno has shared with him - a fact that the terrified Bruno denies.The mother discovers the truth about the 'farm' and the smoke stacks and sinks into a depression, loathing that her husband is in charge of such atrocities.  Gretel becomes transformed as a Hitler youth under the influence of the children's tutor (Jim Norton) and there are obvious philosophical schisms in the family.  Bruno, regretting his treatment of Shmuel, continues to sneak food to him and plans to help his young friend save Shmuel's father: Bruno digs into the 'farm' and the results bring the film to a terrifying and abrupt end.Both young actors give enormously moving performances and the manner in which Herman directs the action underlines the blur of perception many German's had about the reality of the Final Solution.  But for what this viewer perceives as the reason the film sustains the powerful message it does is the manner in which it ends. There are no attempts to 'sanitize' this film: it simply ends with a lightning bolt jolt that is one of the most powerful statements in all of the many films about the Holocaust.  It is simply a brilliant masterpiece of a movie from every aspect of judging it - acting, direction, music, cinematography, editing - and why this film failed to make an impression on the critics and public (and the Oscar folks!) when it was released in the theaters remains a conundrum.  Highly recommended for all audiences. Grady Harp, March 09

reviewText: Little Bruno, the son of a Nazi officer, does not understand why the people in his world think Jews are bad. He doesn't understand why a man who's really a doctor is working as a potato peeler in his kitchen. And, he doesn't get why a boy about his age has to stay on the other side of a barbed wire fence and go around in his pajamas all day. But that boy, Shmuel, is the only friend he can find near his new house. Almost every day, Bruno throws his ball out too far "by accident" and runs to get it, as an excuse to run to the barbed wire fence where he spends time with his friend.Throughout this film, you can get a sense of how much or how little Germans knew about the Holocaust when it was happening. Some had a general idea of what was going on, while others were blind to what their country was doing. On the one extreme, Bruno was almost completely ignorant about what was happening to Jewish people. On the other, his dad and his dad's coworkers were the ones exterminating. Bruno's sister grew to be more nationalistic and pro-Nazi as the story continues, and his mom wasn't a fan of Jews but also couldn't live with the grief that her husband was murdering them in cruel and unusual ways. Because of his mom's sentiments, Bruno, his mom, and sister were going to go live with relatives in Heidelberg. But something happens that gets in the way of a peaceful transit to the city.This movie is NOT based on a true story; however, it is still just as dark and tragic as many of the other popular films about the Holocaust, maybe even more so. Anyone who has liked watching movies like The Pianist and Schindler's List should see this one! I saw the commentaries and deleted scenes too. The actors and crew who were interviewed explained their roles and related it to the way people like their character in 1940s Germany must have felt. The deleted scenes include Bruno seeing the concentration camp from his window, and his maid looking for him. They are very minor parts and not really amazing, but I guess that's why they're deleted scenes.I have two small complaints against the movie. One is that all the characters have a British accent! Yes, most of the actors were of British descent, but it didn't make any sense in the context of the movie! Also, it is a bit unrealistic that a German and Jewish boy are able to meet at the fence all the time, without a soldier punishing at least the Jewish one. Despite these two imperfections, it really is a great movie.
summary: Not a true story, not entirely realistic, but AMAZING anyway

reviewText: This film is a prodigy of horror wrapped up in love and that horror destroys this love forever by making it eternal in death.Two eight year old boys meet, one on the free side of the fence, the other one on the camp side of the fence of a "work camp" (a nice name indeed for a Konzentration Kamp) for Jews just when the final solution is introduced. In GermanyI will neglect the side of the Commandant of the camp who is a SS and yet also has a personal life, a wife, two children, parents, a father who is on the good side and a mother who is clearly critical. A promotion for a SS officer is to become a camp Commandant and do, under strict secrecy, what is expected from him: to build a better German nation without any Jews, and if possible a world in the image of that German nation.The film shows very well how the whole ideology is built on propaganda, which is a pack of lies, or ,if you prefer a pack of lying wolves that are after you to get your souls down into hell, in the name of the Greater future of the German nation. There is not much to say about the details of that machine. The details are there, clear and obvious. No comment, just cry with rage at such dumb inhumanity, really for both sides, the German nation itself and their victims.The film is a lot more interesting with the eight year old son of that SS Commandant who escapes from the home of Herr Kommandant to  explore the forest behind the mansion and come to the fence where he discovers an eight year old Jewish boy who is hungry and sad, Shmuel. Shmuel has nothing to learn about the life outside the camp, but the other boy, Bruno, has to discover what the camp is and that it is no YMCA simmer camp. That takes time and a treason in the middle, but boys will be boys and they will invent a project to come together. Since Shmuel cannot come to the outside why not Bruno going into the camp.And that will be the drama. No survivors please with the final solution, and frankly it's better like that. Which of the two boys could have survived without being damaged for life, or till death ensues.And the film can end on the tears of the mother and sister and on the despair of the SS Commandant of a father. We will not be given the logical end for him after such a tragedy. Death at times can be sweet and desirable.This is a masterpiece of poignancy even if suspense (who cares about suspense in a subject we all know by heart and regret with all our hearts) is rather light because boys will be boys and boys have always been boys. And love, or call it friendship if you prefer being a prude, has no limits, no divides, no abyss in the middle. Love is unified by definition and love comes no matter what and is for life and death. Happy are those who can share a life full of discoveries and then a death full of satisfaction. I am afraid the two boys met in death with apprehension and fear but a lot of courage in their acceptance of that fate as being a fate in which they can hold hands, and they did, naked under the fumes of the death-inflicting shower.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

reviewText: Eight year-old Bruno, (Asa Butterfield), is an innocent, carefree boy growing up in Berlin during WWII. As the film opens, we see him running through the city's streets with his three best friends, their arms outstretched, pretending to be airplane pilots and feigning battles. Seemingly oblivious, they race past scenes of Jews being rounded up to be taken to concentration camps. Bruno, with his wonderful sense of adventure, wants to be an explorer when he grows up.He lives in a beautiful mansion, complete with gardens and servants, along with his twelve year-old sister Gretel, (Amber Beattie), their beautiful mother, (Vera Farmiga), and their father, a high ranking SS officer, (David Thewlis). After Bruno's and Gretel's father receives a promotion, a brand new title, "Commandant," along with a fancier uniform, the family moves to a deserted house in the countryside. The house, a cold and somber place, with SS Stormtroopers everywhere, is actually SS Headquarters. The father's new job is to administer a concentration camp - a death camp - Auschwitz. Bruno is miserable in his new home. He misses his friends and school. There is no one to play with and he is very bored. His father tells him that, "Home is where the family is." And, "Being a soldier is about duty instead of choice." They cannot move back to Berlin.Because there is no school for the children to attend, a tutor is hired to educate them...and he does so from books filled with Nazi propaganda. When the little boy asks him about "nice Jews," the teacher responds, "I think, Bruno, if you ever found a nice Jew, you would be the greatest explorer in the world." Gretel soon begins to model herself after the "ideal" Nazi youth, plastering the walls of her room with photographs of Hitler and children from the Nazi Youth Group, a paramilitary organization of the Nazi Party. Bruno is not buying any of it. His tutor's teachings make no sense to him, given his budding sense of reason, and his earlier, relatively propaganda free, background. His paternal grandmother is anti-Nazi, and his mother is apolitical, but dutifully supportive of her husband.From his bedroom window, the boy notices a town of people dressed in striped pajamas separated from him by a wire fence. He thinks that the people are farmers. He wants to go and play with some of the children he sees, but is forbidden to leave the grounds. When he asks his father who those people are, Dad responds that they aren't really people. Bruno also asks questions about the smoke he sees rising from the "farm" and the terrible smell that accompanies it. When his mother discovers the reality of the camp, all the terrible details, she deteriorates mentally and emotionally into a shallow shell...no longer the vibrant woman we met in the opening scenes.With his avid curiosity and adventurous spirit, the boy finds a way out of the compound and eventually comes to the barbed wire fences surrounding the camp. He is totally bewildered by what he sees. On the other side of the fence is another eight year-old boy, Shmuel, (Jack Scanlon), a broken waif of a child wearing a numbered uniform. Shmuel lives a very different life than Bruno. He is a Jew, and along with the rest of his family, a prisoner in the camp. He sometimes hides by the fence, during work detail, where he meets Bruno and the two form a friendship. Bruno brings food for Shmuel and the two play checkers, with the board on Bruno's side of the fence. But Bruno still doesn't "get it."  The enormity of the evil confronting him is beyond his comprehension. He believes that the numbered striped pajamas are part of a game played inside the barbed wire enclosure. He asks his friend what is burned in the chimneys.Their friendship is an allegory of sorts. Producer David Heyman explained in the press notes that, "Children have the potential and the ability to overcome differences in culture and identity; that people ultimately can get along if they're not encouraged to hate; that governments, institutions and the media can and do cultivate conflict and distrust-- these are timely ideas with universal relevance and I think this story makes them accessible to anyone." At the beginning of the film, a quotation by poet John Betjeman appears on the screen, "Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows.Obviously nothing good can come from this Holocaust story...how can it? The final scenes had a visceral impact on me, and I sat stunned,  in pain, for some time after the movie ended."Striped Pajamas" is based on Irish author John Boyne's critically acclaimed,  award-winning young adult novel of the same title. The book is meant to educate young adults about the Holocaust. Having read the book, I think the film version is much more explicit. I believe that the manner in which the content is depicted, although done with great sensitivity and compassion, is too harsh for a young person to view. I am Jewish, and a mother, and I feel that it is so important to educate all people, especially our youth, about this most heinous event. But I prefer to do so by introducing books, like "The Diary of Anne Frank," before exposing children and "tweens" to such a disturbing drama.Ultimately "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas" is about the beauty of the human spirit. The acting is exceptional, especially the performances by the three talented children, Asa Butterfield, Jack Scanlon and Amber Beattie. I do recommend this film highly. I just want the prospective viewer to be forewarned as to the strength and impact of the narrative.Jana Perskie
summary: "Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows"
Title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas

reviewText: How wonderful it must be to see the world through the eyes of an oblivious child.  There are no jobs, no wars, no famine, no taxes, no real thought of danger.  For a young boy named Bruno (Asa Butterfield), the naivety and innocence could prove to be potentially dangerous.An up-and-coming SS officer (David Thewlis) is given a promotion; and as a result of his new assignment, his family is forced to move.  Traveling from the relative safety of Berlin to a very large, remote house was not what anyone other than the father expected.  Simultaneously supportive and reluctant, his family - especially the mother (played with heart-breaking emotion by Vera Farmiga) - soon realizes their new home is adjacent to an active concentration camp.With more than a passing resemblance to a mini-Hitler, Bruno is a typically adventurous boy.  Having a soldier for a father is a source of pride and admiration for him; he'd love nothing better than to emulate his father.  He initially notices the local "gardeners" in "pajamas" and becomes intrigued.  While exploring the woods in his backyard, something strictly forbidden from by his mother, he comes across the nearby camp and meets Shmuel (Scanlon), an emaciated, filthy eight-year old Jewish prisoner.  The two form a tenuous and dangerous friendship, discussing their childish similarities, but also uncovering at least one significant difference: their feeling towards soldiers.  Neither understands the precariousness of their surroundings, nor do they understand the hideous smells coming from a burning smokestack very nearby.Eventually their shared innocence disintegrates under the pressure of their real world surroundings as Bruno attempts to comprehend why everyone seems to hate the Jews even though his friend Shmuel is such a nice guy.  The final jaw-dropping moment shines light on the possibility of tragedy when one is ignorant, oblivious, or purposefully turning a blind eye to the surrounding dangers.The performances from all are incredibly moving.  Witnessing not only the loss of Jewish childhood via the stolen dignity, humanity, and life itself, but also that of the German childhood manipulated via the indoctrination of Nazi propaganda, truly delivers an incredibly heave message that resonates long after the movie is complete.  Truly stunning, this film does an incredible job at displaying the atrocities of the death camps while providing an invaluable teaching tool.  Highly recommended and emotionally devastating.

reviewText: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is extremely intense, even painful, but so beautifully done that one becomes pulled in.  In this film, we see the holocaust through the eyes of innocence - and the eyes are German.  We experience the story in the heart of a loving family - and the family is German.  Because of that viewpoint, we can understand a little better how people remained morally unchallenged during the holocaust, even when the ghastly truth was literally just outside their gates.  We can see, achingly, that we, as good people, are not immune to allowing that which we now condemn in hindsight.  The film draws parallels between the world of the camp, with the striped clothing those interred there must wear behind electrified fences, and the stark, fortress-like house in which the German commandant's family lives, with it's barred stair rail and locked, guarded fence.  We come to see that both groups are, in very different ways, imprisoned.  The fact that the main characters, Bruno and Schmuel, are each eight years old, allows us to feel tenderly toward them in their different innocent circumstances, and levels our sympathies.  Bruno's mother is a sensitive and nurturing woman, and the daughter dabbles with the Reich teachings  and the Reich heroes in the manner that we'd recognize in a twelve-year-old girl of today idolizing media stars.  We are even shown the loving father inside the proud, severe military commandant.  This makes experiencing the film very difficult, as the viewer becomes emotionally engaged in the friendship between Schmuel inside the camp, and Bruno with his warm German family in their compound.As a retired teacher I recall the difficulties of encouraging young people to understand this time in history.  To them, the holocaust is something that happened long ago, done buy a known monster, and something that they, as modern people, simply wouldn't do.  I wish I'd had this film to help them open their eyes to the commonality of people.  It shows us that Germans of the holocaust were ordinary people, too.  The film is fiction, but somehow it is truer than a documentary because it lets us into the hearts of those who lived in that time, and leads us to recognize that  the kind of thinking that lead to the holocaust is not, most unfortunately, banished to the distant past.  The seeds of the holocaust flowered into horrible fruit then, and the same seeds are within each of us now.  The film shows us through the commandant's innocent family that expressions of hate can devastate the hater as well.  We have an obligation to pass on the story of the holocaust to the current generation, so the mindset which lead to the atrocities can be recognized and avoided. Though it is difficult viewing, parents should watch it with children whom they judge capable, so that the priceless understanding that comes through the film will not be lost to the future.

reviewText: Il margine del rasoio taglia attraverso questo dramma di Olocausto di seconda guerra mondiale potente "Il Bambino la Truffa Il Pigiama UN Righe" con nessun rimorso. Testimoniamo di prima mano in questo film le atrocità di un campo di concentramento e la normalità di una famiglia, un Ralf di padre (il S l'ufficiale che è il comandante di campeggio), l'Elsa di madre (che crede che suo marito sovrintenda un campo di lavoro, une poi scoperte fuori da è un campeggio di morte), il loro 13 anno vecchio Gretel di figlia (che abbraccia ingenuamente il proganda di nazista), ed il loro 8 anno vecchio Bruno di figlio (che aiuta segretamente un 8 anno Il vecchio ragazzo Ebreo ha nominato Shmuel nel campeggio e determina di propria iniziativa - che la propaganda è falso basato sulle sue proprie osservazioni di famiglie Ebree e le sue conversazioni con l'altro ragazzo).Questa rivelazione da Bruno guida il complotto. La sua amicizia con Shmuel cresce in un vincolo forte, molto più vicino del suo rapporto con suo padre, sua madre o sua sorella. Bruno si insinua fuori per vedere il suo amico, i rischi essendo presi - tutto il mentre ascolta le parole ingannevoli,, farisaici, dogmatici delle persone nel campeggio di suo padre. Disegna le sue proprie conclusioni. Bruno inizia a vedere il suo proprio "obbligo nobile" attraverso la prospettiva umile del suo amico vicino, un ragazzo Ebreo. Diventa il nostro eroe nel più vero senso, perché non accetta le bugie, l'inganno, l'ipocrisia, l'intento omicida o la tirannia dei nazisti ed il loro giudizio sugli Ebrei. Inventa la sua propria mente. È superiore al civilizzato malvagio presentato a lui - di andare nel forno di morte con il suo amico vicino. Il sacrificio di Bruno con Shmuel di vita diventa un testamento di alimenterà ed ornerà, a prescindere dagli orrori del campeggio ed il suo metodo di esecuzione. Come un pubblico, cresciamo nella statura testimoniando questa tragedia epica attraverso gli occhi di bambini innocenti.In questo film percepiamo la sorte, teme, l'agonia, la disperazione e soffrendo oltre la comprensione umana. Sappiamo dall' "Elenco dello Schindler" e gli altri film di campo di concentramento - ciò che attende questi internati. Poi fuori da della severità della trama - osserviamo l'umiltà estrema e capendo da parte di due ragazzi. Siamo consentiti identificarsi con loro, anche poiché la loro amicizia è separata dai fili metallici dentellati e dai cani da guardia; anche poiché attendono la collinetta di morte del carnefice insieme - che è un pensiero intorpidito in e di sé. La profondità di carattere ed il complotto abbonda in questo film. L'ironia drammatica è attuale poiché la tirannia indossa la maschera di un ufficiale un poco civilizzato militare con una famiglia un poco normale che deve realizzare in definitiva che ha dato involontariamente all'ordine per sterminare suo proprio figlio. Il gemere angosciato del suo Elsa di moglie risuona l'accettazione silenziosa di madri Ebree che sono guidato nei forni. Il performaces superbo dai caratteristi con esperienza e le attrici fa questo film una realizzazione rara per il suo direttore ed il suo equipaggio. Le unità sono aderite a con la disciplina nel senso di produzione cinematografica.

reviewText: "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a devastating film, powerful and moving, with a startling and completely unexpected, unforgiving ending that sears the viewer and makes the whole movie incredibly significant. At the beginning we see a privileged Nazi family living in Berlin amid street scenes in which almost robotic people go about their business while in the background Jews are being rounded up for the concentration camps.The protagonist, an eight year old boy, Bruno, played superbly by Asa Butterfield is oblivious to what is going on around him. In his play world he is probably a fighter airplane soaring through the skies. Ironically he may be playing war games in his mind. He's a gentle, likable lad who has a loving family.The father, a loyal Nazi, though gentle, kindly as well, is assigned to a post in the country as the commandant of a concentration camp. In their walled compound the boy and his mother see the smoke rising from the nearby high chimney. Their servant is an older man who under his work clothes wears striped pajamas. We are aware of these details through the eyes of the mother and her son.The boy wanders out of the yard and comes upon the barbed wire fence of the camp. He meets an eight year old, Shmuel, also in striped pajamas, who is sad and hungry. They grow to be friends. Bruno is unaware of Shmuel's plight. There is a crucial denial scene in "Striped" just as there was between the two boys in "The Kite Runner."The movie concerns the onset of loss of innocence, and makes real the horrors of the Holocaust. The cinematography is outstanding; the acting is peerless.Can it be that the familial tunnel vision of human beings toward the plight of all humanity will be the downfall of the human species?It's a very significant work, a human drama that should move viewers. There is no phony manipulative sentimentality in this work. Very highly recommended.
Title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas

reviewText: I had not expected this movie to be this good, or for the boys to do such an incredible job acting that they dragged you right in.I served in the military, and spent almost 5 years in Germany, and have gone and visited camps.  And even all the years after the fact, you can still almost feel the horror and despair.  Simply visiting was a horrific experience, because the whole time you are there, you can't help but try to imagine what it was like.  Anyone with the sensitivity of a caterpillar ends up overwhelmed with compassion and loss, numbed and unable to encompass the magnitude of the reality.In all the things I've seen regarding the camps, I've never seen, or even imagined, a story about it portrayed through the eyes of an 8 year old child.  And not just an 8 year old child inside the camp, but an 8 year old child who is outside of it, innocent of what is going on while his father is the German running the camp.  An 8 year old who befriends a Jewish boy interred in the camp his father runs, neither really understanding the full reality.  And watching as the little German boy starts to wonder, to question, to learn that the lies he was fed were just that, lies.Watching the story unfold, drawing you along with it, starting out so innocently, and seeing as the people who were unaware start to become aware...  It was masterfully done.  I have to get the book now.Such a simple premise for a story, but such a powerful one.  It's one of those movies that will be with you for a long time...

reviewText: This is a film adaptation of a book of the same name by John Boyne.  Although completely fictional and highly improbable, the movie has a visceral punch that will literally knock the wind out of you.  Briefly, the movie is about a German family in which the father become the commandant of a Jewish concentration camp (in the book, the camp is identified as Auschwitz).  The story-line unfolds as though we are seeing the events happen through the wide-eyed naive eyes of Bruno, the eight-year-old son of the commandant.  Bruno quite accidentally forms an unknowing friendship with another 8 year old boy, but this boy, the boy in the striped pajamas on the other side of the fence, is a Jew. Bruno is completely ignorant of what is happening in the camp, which he believes to be a farm. When the commandant's wife realizes that the camp is a death camp, (apparently she too is blissfully unaware of the purpose of the camp), she has a falling out with her husband and demands to take the children away.  On the very day they are set to leave, events occur that lead to the climactic and sobering ending.While thoroughly improbable in terms of the plot, in my opinion, this film still packs a powerful punch.  Critics, many of them Jewish critics, assailed this film for its improbability and for the naivete of the characters, in effect implying that the typical German citizens of the day did not know the meaning or intent of the death camps.  This is a valid criticism, but in the film's defence, this again is NAZI Germany seen through the eyes of a boy.  It is not meant to be a film that exposes all the evils of the Jewish Final Solution. reviewText: I just returned from taking 3 young boys(ages 9-11) to see this film.  They are all pretty mature and know a lot about the Holocaust already, but I think that this film made them realize the actual horror of the Holocaust in a way that books can't.  That the story is told through the eyes of a very precocious 8-year-old kept their interest, even though virtually all the film's violence is implied or happens off-screen. I had no idea the film ended as it did, and we all walked out in silence.  Yet, the more we discussed it on the way home, the more we saw the irony--well, perhaps poetic justice, in a sense-- of the film's message of evil and the way it takes root, and how you can't participate in it and still keep yourself and your family separate from it.  The message is transferable to so many modern situations that this alone makes the film worthwhile.  Yes, the boys' conversations would have been spotted very quickly--yes, the ending requires you to take a leap of logic...but the performances and the moral of the movie render it worthy of a viewing.  By the way, Vera Farmiga as Bruno's mother is superb.

reviewText: I've watched many great film adaptations of books written about the Holocaust and how it affected all involved.  Yet, THE BOY IN THE STRIPPED PAJAMAS, was probably the most heart-breaking movie I've seen because it showed in chilling details how two young boys - one Jewish, one German, became innocent victims of Hitler's Nazis madness to exterminate Europe of non-Aryans.  The movie was all the more powerful and heart-wrenching in its portrayal of the hedonist perpetration of human extermination because the two main child characters [eight-year-old Shmuel, 'the boy in the stripped pajamas', and eight-year-old, Bruno 'the son of the Commandant responsible for the extermination camp were Shumel is held captive'] are exemplary in their roles of capturing children's naivety and inability to comprehend the unthinkable.Other reviewers have written in great detail about the specifics of the plot.  It is multi-layered and complex, examining the the characters who portrayed participants and victims of a an evil event in recent history, and the effects it had on each.  Instead, I prefer to focus my comments on why I believe this movie is so important.In my opinion, we underestimate the innocence of young children and their gullibility, their 'magical thinking' to believe in an idealistic world, and the pureness of their hearts to believe the best in their parents; failing to see, imagine, or comprehend any flaws. Even when young children are exposed to the 'worse' of abusive conditions, most don't grasp the depth of their circumstances.  For this reason [among others] children are easily manipulated to do what they are told by predators; coerced to believe in angels and gifts when they obey, or condemned to be tormented by monstrous demons if they don't comply.Because of the subtleties in the manner the scenes are directed, rather than the 'overtness' obvious to us as adults, the dialogue between Bruno and Shumel made this movie all the more chilling to watch.  As viewers, we watch their friendship blossom knowing they have already become unsuspecting victims.  Through the innocent and loyal camaraderie that we witness between Bruno and Shumel - two 'sacrificial lambs' - we discover the unimaginable horror, power, magnitude, and atrocity of the Holocaust.THE BOY IN THE STRIPPED PAJAMAS is a movie to be watched by families who have teenagers.  It is a film I'll long remember.Maizie Lucille JamesJanuary 14, 2012
summary: Heartbreaking Story of Innocence During Nazis Rule

reviewText: What was most memorable about this movie is that even when people understood what was happening, and were adamantly opposed to it, they still did nothing about it. The grandmother in the movie was obviously aware and opposed from the beginning, but said almost nothing. There is some question about what really happened to her in the movie, but she was such a peripheral character I can't write much about it.The mother in the film was such a coward when she understood the horror of the camp, yet still allowed her children to be indoctrinated by their tutor. When she saw her daughter with a crush on an especially cold and cruel young officer, she never tried to dissuade her daughter from forming an attachment. When a prisoner showed her son kindness and took care of him when he was hurt, all she could manage was a perfunctory, unemotional word of thanks. And when that same prisoner lost his life for a simple mishap, she said not one word as he was killed. She did fight with her husband about it, but she could have done so much more.I think, as a mother myself, the character of the mother in this story was a tragic figure because of her lack of words and action to do anything to even make the life of the prisoners (two were in the house during the movie) even a little bit better. A kind word, an offering of food--but no, she did not do one single thing. Then, at the end of the movie, she suffered what no mother should suffer and partially because of her apathy of evil.The acting in this movie is excellent (although it is odd that every person seems to have a British/Irish accent--definitely not German or Polish--which is distracting to the authenticity of the story) from the children (how do young people become so talented at such young ages?) to the adults. Every character is important to the movie, but the character of the mother is most memorable to me.I would recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in history (just try to ignore the accents) and would like an unusual story of that time from a different perspective, as seen from a children's eyes, from both sides of the barbed wire.

reviewText: The Mrs. and I just rewatchedSchindler's List (Widescreen Edition)and that masterpiece made us interested in the recent "Boy in the Striped Pajamas".Have you not often wondered what the good people of Germany were thinking as Hitler codified anti-Semitism and six million Jews were murdered?  This film shows that not everyone was in lock-step with the mindless prejudices that would allow otherwise "good" people who looked the other way while unspeakable evil walked the earth, but the evil viewpoint was the one that prevailed.Bruno (Asa Butterfield) is much like other eight year old boys.  He is curious and loves his family.  His family provides a comfortable home and a loving environment.  Bruno's father is a soldier, and Bruno takes some pride seeing his father in his uniform.  Bruno's father is receiving a promotion and an assignment to an important new post.At the new assignment Bruno sees workers at the farm where his father is the overseer.  Curious - all the workers wear dull black and white striped pajamas.If we know even a little about the holocaust, it is curious to see if through the eyes of eight-year-old Bruno.  Bruno is lonely in his new home - there are no other young children.  On the other side of the barbed wire his new friend, Shmuel, has the opportunity to play with the other workers.We see the horror as Bruno's mother (played by Vera Farmiga) realizes that dear old Dad is the kommandant of a Death Camp rather than a work camp.  She is horrified, and like the Kommandant's mother, not in agreement with the "final solution".  But their voices are in the minority, and drowned out by the prevailing opinion of the inherent "evilness" of the Jews.This film does not break new story-telling ground.  But by telling the story from a point of view that we rightly expect to be innocent, and shielded from horror - we feel the horror more nearly than from an history book.In scope and tone and story and setting and cinematography inferior to Speilberg's masterpiece, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is nonetheless a worthwhile film.
summary: All that is necessary for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing - Edmund Burke

The boys continue their friendship through the fence and in an attempt to apologize to Schmuel for lying, Bruno sneeks across (or under) the fence to help Schmuel find his father who has gone missing within 'the farm'.  The Nazi Commander and his wife discover their son is missing and start a frantic search to find their son.  The movie then takes an unexpected turn (although, somewhat expected if you know any history about concentration camps) and it's at that moment when your emotions are truly put to the test. reviewText: First, let's start off by saying that the subject matter is not the easiest and some will find this a difficult film to watch.  But I urge you to do so.  It is a haunting film, one that will make you think and also understand the emotional scope of the horrors that happened in Nazi Germany.The script (adapted from the novel by John Boyne) is tight, the dialog and characters defined as much by what the characters do not say as they are by their words, deed and actions.  The casting is spot on as well, with Jack Scanlon as Shmuel turning in a heartbreaking performance, full off the innocence of youth tamped down by the horror around him.  Likewise, David Hayman as Pavel turns in an understated performance to serve as counterbalance to Shmuel.  Pavel has seen it all, plunged from the heights to the lowest of lows.  He is a broken man and yet he has not lost his humanity.  Asa Butterfield turns in a nice performance as Bruno, the son of the Nazi Commandant, and Vera Farmiga as Bruno's mother gives a nuanced performance as the woman who has her head in the sand but her eyes wide open.  And stunningly frightening is Henry Kingsmill as the explosive Nazi officer, Karl.  And David Thewlis as the steady and determined Commandant is equally effective.The direction combined with the writing is what makes this film really sail.  The contrast between the innocence of the two boys and the action going on about them is powerful, creating a view of racism that seems all the more horrible when seen through the eyes of children who don't understand what is happening, what it all means.Difficult and challenging, this film is an important look at racism and the massive sins of the Nazi regime.  It takes an event which seems both far away and achingly near to us in the time line and creates a truly horrifying and moving portrait of what can happen when madmen go unchecked.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: This was quite a remarkable, and somewhat shocking film. Based on the novel by John Boyne, the story follows 8 year old Bruno, the son of an SS officer in 1942 Nazi Germany. The film starts out innocent enough. As Bruno and his friends make their way through the streets of Berlin playing, one could almost mistake this for any other given European city in peacetime. Everything seems alright with the world, and even Bruno's father the SS man is a loving family man. Everything changes when father gets promoted, and the family has to move to a new house in the country. What Bruno doesn't realize is that his father has just taken over as Commandant of a concentration camp. In fact, Bruno doesn't even know what such a camp is, or what its purpose would be. Thus he is perplexed when out exploring one day, he comes to the camp fence and meets a boy his own age on the other side. They develop a friendship, and the story culminates in a somewhat startling denouement. The film also gives some interesting insight into family life in Nazi Germany; it's always odd to see a Death's Head insignia sporting killer behaving as any other dad would. I must say, there did seem to be something slightly far-fetched about the story, Bruno's complete naivete, etc, not to mention the English accents. But minus that, I found this to be a very sad yet compelling story that successfully portrays this horrific period through a child's eyes. Definitely worth checking out.

reviewText: We have all heard of the horrors of concentration camps and seen some documentaries and feature films. But none of them could have the same impact as this film. That is because this movie looks at the Holocaust from the perspective of two children, one within the camp and one outside. Both are caught up in a chain of events dictated by circumstances beyond their control.Even wars cannot stop children from becoming friends. Children have no enemies. Even as the Nazi propaganda machine denigrates Jews, Bruno, the eight-year-old son of a senior SS Officer forms a friendship with an eight-year-old boy in the concentration camp located just beyond their house. Both of them have little idea of what is going on. Genocide is a concept they know nothing about.This movie evokes memories of the Italian movie Life is Beautiful, because they both focus on children caught up in war. But the message that emanates from The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is even more powerful. Life is not only beautiful, it is precious. How could a man with a family send so many innocents to their deaths? That is a pivotal point in the film. When Bruno's father realizes the futility of his actions, it is too late.This is one of the best movies centered on World War II. There's not a gunshot in sight, but the smoke from the chimneys is all that is needed to show the depths to which man could sink in times of war. It will appeal to children and adults alike - this movie is a good teaching aid as well if you want to tell your children about the Holocaust. Shot on location in Hungary, the period costumes, cars and houses in the film look authentic. This a must-see for all.

reviewText: This film was really pretty good, but it has some problems I couldn't get past. The first thing I found only slightly irritating is that it took a bit of time to get used to american and British actors playing Germans who spoke with a British accent. Not a major problem of course but none the less it was a little bit of an annoyance. Secondly, I am having a very hard time believing that such an event could have actually happened. Not knowing if this film is based on a true story or not had me wondering that if it did happen, how? There was some things that didn't make sense. For instance a German boy befriends a Jewish boy by secretly sneaking off from his home near a concentration camp where the Jewish boy was imprisoned. He goes to the site to see what it was really like there out of an adventurous spirit. Anyway the friendship that develops between these two boys happens in broad daylight, through a fence that is in plain view of risen guard shacks around the camp. The two play games like checkers, and the German boy brings food and often passes it through the fence to the Jewish boy. So it's very hard to swallow that no Nazi guard saw any of this at all and attempted to put a stop to it. The story as a whole only works if the situation is believable. But based on the very small concrete pile that was meant to hide the goings on between the two boys, it simply is not plausable that within the visual representation that this friendship could have ever happened. If it did and the story is true then the film fails to make the scenario believable. I also found it difficult to believe that this very intelligent German boy could remain so clueless about this camp and not at least know something very bad was going on in there. Basically though this film tells a much different story than other films about the Holocaust and it was very well acted and well made, and I was happy to see that there was nearly no violence in the entire film.
summary: Actually very good but sadly there are some hard to ignore weaknesses

reviewText: A story of innocence against a diabolical truth. It is set in WW11, but really it could happen anytime, anywhere. For in reality, it is a story of mankind's struggle within Himself.Seeing the cover of DVD with two innocent children, one in pajamas, next to a barbed wire fence; I knew in my gut that this was Tombstone Territory Hardcore. Experience weathers the face of innocence, laugh lines troubled by worry lines next door to evil. Some live in evil's mist never knowing; many Germans have claimed suprise over the Holocaust, some even denying it. In 2000 there were a suspected 5,000 to 7,000 camps. Today we know there were over 20,000 such camps. Six known extermination camps, 12,000 ghettos of starvation, 10+ million slave laborers, 10+ million POWs, and thats not counting other types of camps. Each camp was an island unto itself with many independent bureaucracies, giving free reign to their many independent commandants, to have absolute power over thier prisoners. Even today the truth is still slowly coming to light.In this fabled/allegorical movie the fence represents a fact. The fence is seperating the two innocent children and they both wonder at its purpose. On one side, hunger & abuse. The other, an abundance of food/toys. Both wonder what the truth is. The irony, of course, is that both are being protected from it (sound familiar?). This brings to my mind an observation by the screenwriter Robert McKee, "What happens is fact. Truth is what we think about what happens.".Shumel, the boy inside the fence, is close to death's door and not aware of it. Bruno, son of the SS officier running the camp, is just as unaware of the fact that this where the ovens of hell on earth are burning. A holocaust of inhumanity so diabolically evil that it cloaks itself in plain sight/shadowed by its very own unbelievable reality.By keeping the truth from the boys, they know not what they do. When they dig a hole. Are they digging their way out/in/ or their own graves? The truth is killing them, not protecting them. The only ones protected by the truth are those that keep it from us, keepers of the darkness that fears the light of day.The Founding Fathers knew that a secret government is a bad government. That power corrupted. The Germany of the 1930's had passed from the light into the darkness quickly/quietly, as quick the rest of the world followed...into hell.The two inocent children here should have been told the FACTS. This week was the week of 9/11. More than one third of Americans do not believe the government's official findings. There are secrets. There are truths. What we must demand are the FACTS. History may not repeat itself but it Damn sure rhymes.So this movie is very prescience in its meaning and message. Fences are still being built. Don't depend on the Goebbels of today. You just have to dig out the Damn truth yourself.But remember, when you find the truth, it just may be.... unbelievable.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED !!!!!

reviewText: Of all the Holocaust dramatizations I've ever seen, this one was easily the most contrived. Though I really wanted to like it, I quickly realized it wasn't going to be able to live up to the expectations I had for it.Not knowing a great deal about the plot beforehand, the idea of a movie about the Holocaust approached from the perspective of a young German boy seemed a really intriguing idea. But in translating that idea to film, something was lost.Though it might seem an inconsequential and trivial point to some, as an English film with English actors, for me, a good deal of credibility was lost up front. And there were other problems here. The notion of a camp inmate being able to slip away unnoticed, presumably about the same time each day, to talk, play, and share food with his young German companion - who would ultimately be able to dig under the electric fence that divided them, also unnoticed, seemed particularly far-fetched. What's more, the wife of the Nazi commander who is responsible for operations at Auschwitz has no clue that Jews were being sent there to die, or that her husband is there to make sure this happens according to plan. At times she even seems sympathetic to the plight of the Jews, thanking the prisoner who worked in her house for bandaging her son's knee, wincing when he is beaten, and looking on with an obvious sense of disapproval in finding her daughter's bedroom plastered with Nazi images, even questioning what the new tutor was teaching her children. The notion of an unsuspecting, compassionate woman as the wife of a high-ranking Nazi official was perhaps the hardest idea of all to swallow. Was the intention here to soften a much harsher reality because that reality - that she knew exactly what was going on and agreed fully with her husband that Jews could not be considered people - was too much to ask viewers to digest?Other things were "off" here as well. The way in which the two boys communicate with each other, particularly in the beginning, seems more befitting men many years older than a couple of eight year olds. And young Bruno's perception of the concentration camp as a farm, its inmates as pajama-clad strangers, and the prisoner in his house as a man who willingly "gave it all up" (meaning his career as a doctor) to peel potatoes - which should have been able to come off as genuine enough as an eight year old's observation - somehow didn't.The young boys were really quite good actors, so kudos to them. I can't say the same for the actresses who portrayed the mother and sister - their performances were a bit on the bland side. And David Thewliss, an actor I've admired for some time, was simply miscast here.All this aside, the last twenty minutes build in intensity to deliver a final unexpected wallop - powerful enough to almost overlook the problems unraveled in the first hour.Though it could have been a lot better, the film makes a point about the utter senselessness of man's inhumanity to man, and if it makes young people interested in learning more about the Holocaust, then in the final analysis, it was an important film.

reviewText: I never read this book, but it's one that after watching this movie, I wish I had.  The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is a nice slow paced film that has sort of a "day in the life of" feel to it.  Young Bruno is 8 years old and pretending to be an airplane flying through the streets of Berlin playing with his friends.  When he arrives home, he discovers that he has to move away and leave his friends.  His father, a German Commander, has to go away because he has a new job and he's taking his family with him.At first, Bruno's new home seems very office-like and cold, until a distant farm he can see from his bedroom window catches his interest.  But the farm seems odd.  All the farmers are wearing striped pajamas.  A tutor comes to teach Bruno and his sister.  His sister soon loses all interest in her dolls and turns to the current events - the war and the extermination of the Jews.  But Bruno doesn't understand.  He wants to get outside the garden walls and away from the house to go exploring.  When he finally escapes, he approaches the barbed wire fence surrounding the "farm" and he finds another 8 year old boy like himself on the other side of the wire.For me, Bruno's niavity of the situation is a lot like the way America was during the Holocaust.  Bruno is proud of his father, but he has no idea that his father is in charge of an extermination camp.  He has no idea what takes place in the camp.  He even sees a propaganda film which makes the camp appear like a vacation and Bruno thinks his father is a good man.  But unfortunately, commanders in such positions had to swear on their life.  They couldn't even tell their wives what was happening.  We see this in the movie as the relationship between husband and wife begins to fall apart when Bruno's mother discovers what is happening after she asks the commander's assistant about the foul smell in the air coming from the chimneys.In the meantime, Bruno steals food to take to his friend, but he doesn't know why his new friend doesn't like to play ball over the fence. Why is it dangerous?  And why must his friend always run away when the horn sounds?  When his new friend gets a chance to come to Bruno's house to clean the drinking glasses, Bruno gives him a snack but a guard catches him.  Bruno lies and says he doesn't know the boy and that he stole the food.  Bruno returns to the barbed wire fence for several days, eager to apologize, but his friend is not there.  Of course, you fear the worst thinking the boy has been killed due to Bruno's actions, but the young prisoner soon returns.  To make up for what he did, Bruno wants to help the boy find his father, but he soon discovers his friendship with the boy in the striped pajamas could have dangerous consequences.Most of us have been touched by the story of Anne Frank or some other Holocaust story that we read in our history books or saw in the movie theater.  This movie will be no different for you.  The innocence you see on the screen just in the two boys' eyes alone will pierce your heart and haunt you.  Like me, you'll probably hold your breath through most of it as if you were walking on egg shells.  Holocaust movies rarely have a happy ending, but I'm not going to spoil this ending for you.  I'll just say that you will indeed come away a better person after seeing this film!
summary: The Holocaust Through the Eyes of a Child

reviewText: "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is an unusual story of the Holocaust.  Bruno (Butterfield) is an eight-year-old boy living in Nazi Germany.  In fact, Bruno's life is great:  he lives in a big house, playing with friends, and enjoying life to the fullest.  His father (Thewlis) is a German officer, and the entire family is proud of him.  That pride grows even larger when the father, an SS officer, gets promoted; a move that requires the entire family to move east to the "countryside".The first signs that there might be something wrong emerge as Bruno peeks through the window of his room, looking at the strange farmers who all wear pajamas.  Bruno doesn't understand why, upon his inquiry of the strangely dressed people, his window is boarded up, and Bruno is not allowed to play in the back yard.  It is even more strange that one of these farmers works in Bruno's family's kitchen, peeling potatoes and never speaking or even looking up.  Bruno does not understand why this man is peeling the potatoes after he finds out that the man is doctor by training, after Bruno fell and hurt himself.In fact, Bruno does not know that he is living immediately next to Auschwitz and that his father is the Camp commander.  With the typical curiosity of a child, Bruno goes into the thin strip of forest behind his house, and goes all the way to the barbed wire, behind which he encounters a boy his own age; this boy also wore striped pajamas.  The two boys, unaware of the politics, religion, or ancient hatreds, strike up a friendship, each boy lonely and starving for companionship.  And although separated by the barbed wire, the boys look forward to Bruno's sneaking out of the back yard, and to having simple conversations every day.  But Bruno must be careful lest his parents, or one of their mean uniformed soldier friends find out about Bruno's activities.I didn't know what to think about this film.  Heaven knows I have seen many films about the Holocaust, and while each offers something new, there are only so many ways a story could be told.  However, I had to take into account that the story of Bruno is fictional.  The film blew me away.  No, there were no great special effects or super tragic scenes sparkled throughout the movie.  No, the film is made in a very simple manner, which only adds charm to it.  What got me is the irony of the film, especially in the very end.  The screenwriting is simple, photography good, and editing well done.  Acting is a bit stiff, but Butterfield did a good job in his role.  In the end, the movie left me perplexed and deep in thought, a result that I often yearn for.All in all, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a well-done movie with a controversial ending.  One either loves it or hates it, but it doesn't leave the viewer non-chalant.  Highly recommended.*Film viewed via Netflix streaming, hence no special features review.*** This review also published on Epinions.

reviewText: I give props to any film that delves into the places few others go, and this one does just that.  Despite eight-year-old Bruno's seemingly neverending naveté about the world around him, but specifically, The Fatherland, this drama explores the holocaust, war, and dubious parental morality from the perspective of a child.  The acting is superb, particularly, Farmiga, Thewlis, and Butterfield, and the cinematography is lovely.  My issues with the film were technical, in that I found it bothersome that everyone in the film had British accents, which did sensually detract from the authenticity of the subject matter.  Though it did drag in a few places and could have been shorter as a result, the film manages to bring a new approach to material that is already emotionally charged. The film's perspective actually did break the wall in a manner of speaking, as at one point in the film it switched from what had been Bruno's perspective to a split second of Shmuel's observation, a distraction more than a disruption.  For its ability to personalize the horrors of WWII this film is worth seeing.

reviewText: Set during the World War II holocaust, The Boy In The Striped Pajamas follows the development of the unlikliest friendship between two little boys - one, a Jewish prisoner at one of the Nazis's extermination camps; the other, the son of the commanding officer of that very camp, who in his childhood innocence knows nothing about what his father really does for a living or the real situation of the war around them (which German children were taught had Germany as the 'good guy' and the Allies as aggressors).Shortly after the boy's father is assigned the new commanding officer of the camp and he and his family relocate there (to an expansive manor - the contrast between the comfortable, supposedly civilized lifestyle of the German officers living right next to a death camp is striking), the boy, Bruno, who spends much of his time alone, comes to a wire fence and meets up with the little boy on the other side of it.  The little boy, Shmuel, is very relucant to say anything of his situation, likely knowing that contact with any non-prisoner is forbidden and would have severe consequences.  Bruno, for his part, is puzzled by the fence and why the other boy wears 'striped pajamas' (the prison garb) all the time, but decides, using innocent eight year-old logic, that all the people on the other side of the fence must be farmers who live there and just dress strangely.  Despite their differences, the two become friends, and Shmuel begins to tell Bruno more of his circumstances.  Bruno brings food to the fence for the under-fed Shmuel, and the two play games through the fence.As Bruno is starting to have doubts about why is his father is running such a place, the rest of the family begins to learn more of the true nature of the camp.  Some seem undisturbed and others horrified, and the question of just when did the German people start to realize what was really going on in a major plot thread.  It's appalling to see the Nazi rationale for their actions, the explanations they give that the people on the other side of the fence "aren't really people", the warped propaganda that Bruno and other children are taught during lessons by their tutors.  Eventually, the friendship between Bruno and Shmuel is discovered, although Bruno remains determined to stay loyal to his little friend, leading up to a calamitous and heart-rending end phase of the movie.Briliantly acted and produced, The Boy In The Striped Pajamas is meant to be accessible to younger viewers, so not all of the Nazi brutalities are shown as graphically as they might otherwise be, but it's still a harrowing watch in many places, and the clearly implied incidents are as effective as anything shown outright.  Upsetting and with a large focus on humanity's worst side, it also focuses often on far brighter or more positive aspects, including Bruno and Shmuel's friendship and also the reactions of certain other characters.  In the days when the commander's wife thinks the camp is merely a labour camp (as if that wouldn't be bad enough) with reasonably decent living conditions (at one point we see several characters viewing a Nazi propaganda film about the camps, depicting the workers happily going about basic chores during the day and gathering at night for socialization, entertainment, and dining - a ridiculously far cry from the reality, but very similiar to what the Nazi government actually put in its real-life propaganda) she gets to know some of the prisoners who are forced to work around the family estate, and starts to question what life is really like for these people on the other side of the fence.  Bruno's mother is one of the characters who's more sympathetic toward the Jewish people from the beginning, and even as Bruno starts to realize what's really going on, his mother is beginning to figure out the same conclusions on her own.All in all, it's a dark and uncomfortable watch, but one in which certain moments of beauty and power continue to shine through.  One of the most powerful World War II films ever made, and an extremely moving tale.
summary: Powerful WWII Tale About The Unlikliest Of Friendships

reviewText: This film probably didn't do as well at the box office because most moviegoers go for fun, not to get depressed. It's films like this that are best experienced at home. And it's a film that is an excellent jumping-off point for discussion with young (10 and above, though the two boys whom the film revolves around are only 9) children about the holocaust - which, all too often, seems to be losing its place in history.I won't go into the detail of the plot as that is covered elsewhere on the Amazon site - and in other reviews. It is also important NOT to know how THIS story ends. (We all know how the holocaust ended.) It gives the film its impact.In the standard "Making of" documentary (20 minutes) in the Special Features, we learn from both the Writer/Director, and the author of the book on which the film is based, that they want the film to be watched by families together and used as a discussion tool. The film is rated PG-13 "for Thematic Material involving the Holocaust". There is violence in the images of injured people (and the makeup is very graphic) but much is implied. We learn what is going on in the "work camp" by seeing fleeting images or hearing sounds.At 94 minutes, the film is brief enough so that children will not get bored. It is NOT a film that, in my opinion, should be watched by children under 16 without a parent or other adult to answer questions they might have, or better yet, ask questions of the children to see that they understand.Miramax made the production in partnership with BBC Films and nearly all the cast are British. (We learn in the documentary that that the woman playing the mother seems to be the sole American among the lead actors.) I did have a small problem at the beginning getting used to the British accents of all these characters who are supposed to be in Germany. (I guess I'm used to actors having German accents in films about the Holocaust.) But, after a while, I accepted it and moved on.I have not listened to the director's commentary. And the deleted scenes included in the bonus features don't add much, but it's good they are included.This is not a perfect film but well worth using as a teaching tool. The more that the younger generation knows about the Holocaust the better the chance that it will never be repeated.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: A different take on the "holocaust film" genre

reviewText: "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a Holocaust movie from an intriguing point of view: that of an eight year-old boy. Bruno witnesses acts that must seem bizarre to a child who is struggling to comprehend that adults--even one's own father--can be evil. The proximity of innocence makes the acts of cruelty even more nauseating, even if they aren't of the same epic scope of "Schindler's List" or "The Pianist". Bruno is the very embodiment of curiosity, and luckily he questions the judgment of those who should know better.He moves into the country near a concentration camp and befriends a young boy who is supposedly the "enemy". But instead of pandering to racist rhetoric and being influenced by brainwashed Nazis, he comes to his own conclusions. Is the Jewish boy evil? Has he done anything mean to Bruno? Gradually Bruno realizes that his world is surrounded by lies--the internment camp is not a happy place, the shaved-head boy is not a grubby rodent, and perhaps his father's weaselly smile is hiding something sinister. In fact, Bruno proves to be less of a loyal friend than his imprisoned counterpart, denying knowledge of their friendship, which ultimately torments him and perhaps takes the first painful step toward building his conscience. If the movie had adhered to this formula, it would have been miraculous. But it takes a strange twist at the end...WARNING SPOILERS HEAD! ACHTUNG! CUIDADO!!! DO NOT READ UNLESS YOU HAVE ALREADY WATCHED THE MOVIE! YOU THERE!! THE ONE DROOLING ALL OVER HIS KEYBOARD AFTER MY REVIEW SENT HIM INTO A STATE OF CATATONIA...OR IS IT NARCOLEPSY? AT LEAST THEN THERE WOULD BE A MEDICAL EXCUSE FOR SOMEONE FALLING ASLEEP WHEN READING THIS...ANYWAY......that seems out of synch with the rest of the movie. The movie builds quietly, with subtle skill, then becomes overwhelmingly tragic. The slow-burning tone erupts into a cataclysm. I am at a loss to understand the director's intent. Or, since this movie is based on a children's book, I am confused as to the author's motivation. Is it that the sins of the father are eventually paid upon his son? Bruno sneaking into the camp certainly reveals his character's sense of adventure, and trying to find his friend's father reveals a desire to seek atonement for his recent betrayal, but the ending still seems murky. Is Bruno's father going to renounce the horrors of anti-Semitism after stumbling upon the body of his son, who has choked on Zyklon-B? Is it an accusation against the mother, who knows that her husband is presiding over hell, yet refuses to steal his children away from him? Is Bruno the sacrificial lamb, suffocating on toxic vapor so his sister will learn a lesson? Am I reading too far into this? Does every movie need to have a profound message? Am I too dumb to fathom it?The very fact that I have so many questions makes me suspect the ending was emotionally powerful but logically muddled. The heavy-handedness of it actually took away some of its emotional impact. I was more moved by Bruno's guilt over betraying his friend than I was when he huddled in the shower stall, waiting for a cascade of water that became lung-drowning cyanide. Bruno didn't have to die for the movie to be heartbreaking. His death only makes me scratch my head and wonder why a generous, kind-hearted boy has to strangle to give the film validity.

reviewText: I also have seen many movies about the Holocaust, and this one stands out immensely, by quietly showing the apathy and deceit required of supposedly civilized people, shown in different ways by Bruno's parents. I have read a number of comments that think Bruno was more than a little dim for not getting it, while supposedly Bruno's mother knew nothing about what was really going on at the camps, and I read no comments on that. It would be interesting to me to read an account, an honest account, of what it was like for a Nazi family and how they lived, knowing what was going on. A child knows only what they have been taught, they believe their parents more than anyone in the world, and since all Bruno was told was lies, of course he is going to believe them and want to believe them. He struggled with wanting to love and honor his father and starting to doubt him. The child was only eight! Even though he was seeing the camp with his own eyes, he didn't really know what was going on, no child who had been sheltered and deceived would. The same with Gretel, who also only knew what they wanted her to know, and had not the experience to know better. The Hitler Youth was immensely successful in indoctrination of the children because they are so vulnerable and impressionable.I was sickened when the elderly man was beaten to death in front of the children and no one moved a muscle, and I seriously suspected the actual cause of the grandmother's death, bombing or not, since she was vocally opposed to the Reich. I feared for the life and health of Bruno's mother as well, and don't think the father, brutal and committed to the Reich, would just let her walk away with his children.The ending was immensely powerful, yet I wanted it to have impact on the father other than just personally, otherwise, I didn't see the point. The worst monster can love his child.I don't think it was Auschwitz, which held thousands of people. This one seemed very small, more like a work camp, and not all of them were killing camps, other than by starvation and disease, etc.The boy that played Schmuel was the sweetest boy and his scenes just broke my heart.

reviewText: There are two good things about this film. One is the marvellous performances of its two young leads. The other is the reminder that the top Nazis were often loving and devoted parents, yet they committed some of the vilest atrocities in history. We tend to demonise the Nazis, but the fact is that these monstrous deeds were not committed by aliens from another planet but by people from one of Europe's most civilised countries. Fanaticism of any kind, religious, political, racial, is a terrible thing.However, for me, these are not enough to save the film, which, even to my inexpert eyes, seems ridiculously contrived.Kids in Nazi Germany were indoctrinated from an early age. A kid such as Bruno, son of a senior officer in the Totenkopf SS, would have received an especially big dose of teaching against the evils of pernicious Jewry. Such a child would have run a mile rather than come anywhere near a Jew, never mind actually befriend one. On the other hand, Jewish kids in what appears to be a "Vernichtungslager" (extermination camp) had a minute life expectancy - as useless mouths incapable of working usefully in the work camps associated with the Vernichtungslager, they usually went straight from the train into THAT queue. To find a feeble bit of non-electrified fence with no guard towers just out the back of the commandant's house and for a Jewish kid to find a job that apparently consists of pushing around an empty wheelbarrow, well, it's all too absurd. Not to mention that Shmuel is apparently a German Jew, so Bruno and he have a common language. All the Vernichtungslager were in Poland, and took Jews from all over occupied Europe. How lucky can you be?The only thing missing from this fairy tale is a happily-ever-after ending.
